column1: https://www.joebucsfan.com/2024/12/dont-put-all-your-eggs-in-that-basket/|“Don’t Put All Your Eggs In That Basket”|Bucky fever hasn’t found its way to one prominent Tampa Bay fan who used to wear a Bucs uniform. Joe is almost in disbelief after hearing what former Bucs guard Ian Beckles (1990-1996) was saying about electric Bucs rookie running back Bucky Irving. Irving has yet to miss a game but Beckles says Irving’s various injuries are a massive red flag and fans might want to dial back the hype. “You think at this time next year we’re still going to be talking about Bucky Irving
column2: a guy who’s a rookie and has had back injuries and hip injuries and foot injuries? Alone they’re all terrible
column3: ” Beckles said on his In The Trenches podcast via YouTube. “All together? Don’t put all your eggs in that basket. “Is he talented
column4: yes? … Bucky’s not durable. You didn’t finish two games in a row and I’m to believe going down the way he’s going to be available in the playoffs? You’ve never played football then. It don’t get easier as the weeks go along.” Joe has a big “C’mon
column5: man” for Beckles. Let’s see if Irving grinds through his injuries down the stretch before judging his durability. Beckles referenced Irving being a smaller running
column7: of course. But Joe’s seen plenty of second-year running backs in Irving’s size range explode in their second seasons. Former Falcons RB Devonta Freeman comes to mind as does Tarik Cohen  of the Bears in the past decade. Freeman
column10: was a beast for a few years. Irving was 5-9
column11: 192 pounds at the NFL Scouting Combine. No

column1: https://www.joebucsfan.com/2024/12/49ers-loss-helped-bucs-playoff-chances/|49ers’ Loss Helped Bucs’ Playoff Chances|Lots of mathematics flowing this time of year in NFL circles. The world of calculating Wild Card and division title tiebreakers is in full swing. So last night the 49ers and Rams played an ugly game with Los Angeles (8-6) winning the NFC West rivalry 12-6. That loss by San Francisco (6-8) put more distance between them and the Bucs in a potential chase for the final NFC Wild Card seed. The 49ers own a head-to-head tiebreaker against the Bucs after beating them Nov. 10 at The Licht House. (The Niners have lost four out of their last five since). The major-media data nerds that calculate probabilites for all teams reaching the postseason bumped up the Bucs’ chances after last night. NextGen stats at NFL.com now has the Bucs with a 72 percent chance at reaching the postseason. The New York Times upped Tampa Bay’s postseason shot to 70 percent with a 62 percent shot at a division crown. The 49ers’ remaining three games are against the Dolphins
column2: Lions and Cardinals with only Detroit at home. Ouch! Yes
column3: the Bucs (7-6) will be in excellent shape if they can win three of their next four games. Joe has high hopes
column4: including the No. 3 seed that’s in play for Tampa Bay.|2024-12-13 10:34:00|211|24|6|49ers|49ers’ loss benefits Bucs' playoff chances in tight race.|5|Mixed sentiments

column1: https://www.joebucsfan.com/2024/12/a-q-shipley-the-bucs-are-running-the-sht-out-of-the-ball/|A.Q. Shipley: The Bucs “Are Running The Sh!t Out Of The Ball”|Former Bucs Super Bowl-winning offensive lineman and former Bucs assistant offensive line coach A.Q. Shipley likes what he sees when he watches the 2024 Bucs offensive line go to work. Shipley does a weekly segment on “The Pat McAfee Show” breaking down offensive line play around the league. This week he highlighted the Bucs and fully enjoyed watching their line pound people. “They are running the sh!t out of the ball
column2: ” Shipley said. “They are doing some very good things.” Shipley rattled off stats for which the Bucs are among the league leaders. He seemed in disbelief that the Bucs are just 7-6. Shipley suggested teams with those kinds of offensive stats are usually dominant. However
column3: Shipley is also frustrated with the Bucs. He believes they are playing much better than their record suggests. And he fingers the culprit. “They have all makings to be great
column4: ” Shipley said. “They are just losing it on defense. The defense is losing some games. That’s the difference.” Shipley also pointed out that when the Bucs have Tristan Wirfs pull on a run play
column5: defenders see that big ol’ truck barreling down on them and they quickly make business decisions or go for cheap shots on Wirfs’ legs. It’s all in the video linked above. Enjoy! column1: https://www.joebucsfan.com/2024/12/fixing-rachaad-white/|Fixing Rachaad White|Joe usually has a different take from the majority of Bucs fans when it comes to two aspects of the team. The first is the Bucs’ offensive line. There is little if anything to whine about the Bucs’ offensive line now
column2: but Joe has been a huge supporter of the offensive line for many years. Joe never wanted to run Donovan Smith and Robert Hainsey out of Tampa like so many fans. And Joe didn’t have a panic attack when Luke Goedeke struggled early in his rookie season. Joe has fully different standards for what is good or bad with an offensive line than a lot of fans. If there aren’t five pancake blocks on every series
column3: Joe is convinced many fans holler and stomp about how godawful a line is. The other element is running backs. Oh
column4: Bucky Irving might be the best Bucs’ best draft pick in a while. When is the last time a third-day draft pick has had this kind of rookie impact? Tanard Jackson? But when it came to Ronald Jones and Rachaad White
column6: Joe is like a salmon swimming against the tide. Hell
column8: Joe once took a phone call on the road in a stadium press box from a Bucs fan threatening to beat Joe up for his anti-Martin stance. A few hours later
column9: Martin was a healthy scratch in a key game because
column11: he was ingesting something the NFL bans players from ingesting. Last year
column12: Joe was fully fed up with White as a runner while maintaining White is one of the best receivers out of the backfield in the league (though Irving has better receiving numbers this year). White’s advanced rushing stats were downright terrible. But boy
column13: writing about that really rubbed many fans the wrong way. They loved White (and probably still do). This year? Joe thinks White has turned into a tough runner. He may rarely get breakaway runs but his short runs last week against Las Vegas were tough runs. Physical. Hard-earned like a fullback. White used to be terrible running between the tackles. Not so any longer. Yesterday
column14: Bucs offensive coordinator Liam Coen discussed how when he arrived in Tampa
column15: an assignment was given to him: Awaken White’s inner running back. Make White more decisive. “That has been an emphasis since we got here
column16: ” Coen said. “We’ve had a lot of meetings and conversations and film sessions with Rachaad
column17: showing him where we think he could take the next step. “He’s been bought into that
column18: he’s understood that can help him in his game and as well as
column20: help us and help us run the football more effectively.” Coen admitted that yes
column21: he has changed how the Bucs block up front. Sometimes
column23: running backs perform better behind specific blocking techniques. He seems to think what the Bucs do now is better suited for White
column24: and that’s one reason why his running has improved. Hearing Coen talk
